questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a history of lifting weights presents the next day with back pain, right-sided radiculopathy, loss of bladder function, loss of sensation of the feet, and weakness of the extensor hallucis longus. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Presents with asymmetric radiculopathy, saddle anesthesia, loss of bladder control, and lower motor neuron signs
  • Typically due to massive central disc herniation, especially in the context of physical strain (e.g., heavy lifting)
  • Involves compression of the lumbosacral nerve roots, not the spinal cord itself

Explanation of other options:

Lumbar canal stenosis (Option A): Typically presents with chronic neurogenic claudication and bilateral symptoms. Does not usually cause acute bladder dysfunction or focal radiculopathy.

Fracture of lumbar vertebrae (Option B): Requires significant trauma. Neurological symptoms occur only if there is cord or nerve root compression, which is not indicated directly in this case.

Conus medullaris syndrome (Option C): Also causes bladder dysfunction, but is characterized by symmetric symptoms, early bladder involvement, and less radicular pain. This case shows asymmetric radiculopathy with delayed bladder signs, favoring cauda equina syndrome.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cauda equina syndrome = asymmetric nerve root symptoms, bladder dysfunction, saddle anesthesia
  • Conus medullaris = symmetric symptoms, early bladder signs, less radicular pain
  • It must be diagnosed early via MRI and treated with emergency decompression.

questions.text: Investigation of choice for entrapment neuropathy is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Electromyography (EMG) and Nerve Conduction Velocity (NCV) studies provide a functional assessment of nerve integrity, localization, and severity of entrapment
  • They are highly sensitive for detecting nerve compression, demyelination, or axonal loss
  • Essential for confirming diagnosis, especially in carpal tunnel or ulnar nerve entrapment

Explanation of other options:

CT Scan (Option A): Limited in soft tissue resolution; not useful for nerve imaging or functional assessment.

Clinical examination (Option B): Helps in suspicion and localization but lacks objectivity and quantification; cannot confirm diagnosis alone.

MRI (Option C): Useful for anatomic detail and soft tissue visualization, but does not assess nerve function; can be supportive but not the primary tool.

Key Takeaways:

  • EMG/NCV is the gold standard for entrapment neuropathy
  • Provides localization, severity, and type of nerve damage
  • Other modalities may be adjuncts but not definitive.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with right-sided lower limb weakness following a recent episode of lumbar disc prolapse. On neurological examination, when asked to extend the knee, he can lift the leg against gravity, but cannot resist manual pressure applied by the examiner. Deep tendon reflexes are diminished, and sensation over the anterior thigh is reduced. What is the corresponding power grade for the affected muscle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Grade III power is defined as the ability to move the limb against gravity but not against any applied resistance
  • In this case, the patient can extend the knee against gravity but fails to resist the examiner's pressure, fitting Grade III.
  • Muscle strength grading follows the Medical Research Council (MRC) scale, where Grade III marks the transition from gravity-eliminated movements (Grade II) to anti-gravity movements (Grade III).

Explanation of other options:

Grade I (Option A): Only flicker of movement is present, no limb movement.

Grade II (Option B): Full range of motion is possible but only in a gravity-eliminated plane (i.e., not against gravity).

Grade IV (Option D): Patient can move the limb against some resistance, but strength is less than normal.

Key Takeaways:

  • MRC Grade III = movement against gravity only
  • Essential in neurological localization and rehabilitation planning
  • Always test in a standardized manner, comparing with the contralateral side.

questions.text: Which of the following sentences is not true about spinal shock?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Spinal shock refers to the temporary loss of all neurologic activity (motor, sensory, reflex, and autonomic) below the level of a spinal cord injury
  • During spinal shock, all reflexes, including the bulbocavernous reflex, are absent, and their return signifies the end of spinal shock; hence, its presence is not consistent with ongoing spinal shock
  • Flaccid paralysis is typical due to loss of descending motor input
  • Visceral paralysis, such as bladder and bowel areflexia, commonly occurs
  • Sensory loss below the level of injury is part of the syndrome

Explanation of other options:

Flaccid paralysis (Option B): True - results from sudden disruption of descending motor pathways

Visceral paralysis (Option C): True - includes bladder, bowel, and sexual dysfunction

Sensory loss (Option D): True - complete loss of all sensations below the lesion

Key Takeaways:

  • Absent reflexes, including bulbocavernous, are key to diagnosing spinal shock.
  • Return of reflexes (especially bulbocavernous) marks the end of spinal shock.
  • Differentiate from neurogenic shock, which is hemodynamic in nature.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the condition where a vertebra is displaced either anteriorly or posteriorly relative to the vertebra below it?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Spondylolisthesis refers to the slippage of one vertebra over the one beneath it, either anterior (most common)or posterior
  • It often results from spondylolysis, trauma, or degenerative changes
  • Can lead to back pain, nerve compression, and spinal instability

Explanation of other options:

Spondylosis (Option A): Refers to degenerative changes in the spine, particularly the intervertebral discs and facet joints

Spondylitis (Option B): Refers to inflammatory conditions of the spine, e.g., ankylosing spondylitis

Spondylolysis (Option D): A defect in the pars interarticularis of the vertebra, often a precursor lesion to spondylolisthesis

Key Takeaways:

  • Spondylolisthesis = vertebral displacement/slippage
  • Most common type: anterolisthesis (anterior slip)
  • Associated with back pain and neurologic symptoms

questions.text: What is the appropriate management for a stable cervical spine injury with no neurological deficits?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In a stable cervical spine injury without neurological involvement, conservative management is preferred
  • A rigid cervical brace provides external immobilization, allowing for healing and preventing further injury
  • It avoids the risks associated with invasive procedures and is effective in maintaining alignment

Explanation of other options:

Skull traction (Option A): Used mainly for unstable cervical injuries or for alignment before surgery, not indicated in stable injuries

Laminectomy (Option C): A decompressive surgical procedure, typically reserved for spinal cord compression or neurological compromise

Anterior decompression and fixation (Option D): An invasive surgical approach, indicated for unstable fractures or neurological deficits

Key Takeaways:

  • Stable cervical spine injuries without neuro deficits are managed conservatively
  • A rigid cervical brace provides adequate immobilization and support
  • Surgery is reserved for unstable injuries or those with neurological symptoms

questions.text: A patient presents with suspected trauma to the upper cervical spine. Which radiographic view is most appropriate to evaluate the odontoid process and lateral masses of C1 and C2?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The open mouth view (odontoid view) is specifically designed to visualize the odontoid process (dens) and the lateral masses of C1 and C2
  • It is essential in evaluating atlantoaxial alignment, especially in cases of trauma, rheumatoid arthritis, or Down syndrome
  • This view can help detect fractures of the odontoid, subluxation, or increased atlantodens interval

Explanation of other options:

Swimmer's view (Option B): Used to visualize the cervicothoracic junction, not the odontoid process

Water's view (Option C): Best for visualizing the paranasal sinuses, not cervical spine

Schuller's view (Option D): Used to visualize the temporomandibular joint (TMJ), not cervical vertebrae

Key Takeaways:

  • The open mouth (odontoid) view is the investigation of choice for C1-C2 visualization.
  • Critical in diagnosing atlantoaxial instability or odontoid fractures
  • Especially useful in trauma and rheumatoid patients with neck pain.

choices.text: Sensory loss below the point of injury

questions.text: What is the usual presenting feature of Jefferson's Fracture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Jefferson's fracture is a burst fracture of the atlas (C1 vertebra) typically caused by axial loading, such as diving into shallow water or a heavy object falling on the head
  • The most common presenting feature is isolated neck pain without neurological deficits
  • This is because the spinal canal is wide at the C1 level, so neurological involvement is uncommon
  • Sensory/motor loss, paralysis, or autonomic dysfunction only occur if there is significant instability or additional spinal injury

Explanation of other options:

Sensory loss below the point of injury (Option A): Uncommon in Jefferson's fracture due to the spacious spinal canal at C1

Flaccid paralysis (Option B): Seen in high cervical cord injury, not in isolated Jefferson fractures

Bladder and bowel incontinence (Option C): Suggests cord or cauda equina involvement, which is not typical for a C1 ring fracture

Key Takeaways:

  • Jefferson fracture = C1 burst fracture from axial loading
  • Presents with neck pain, often without neurological signs
  • Diagnosed via open mouth (odontoid) view X-ray or CT scan.

choices.text: It is primarily composed of type I collagen
Has a low proteoglycan to collagen ratio
Receives its nutrient supply via diffusion through the vertebral end plates

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the nucleus pulposus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The nucleus pulposus is an avascular structure, and its nutrition is derived via diffusion through the vertebral end plates, which is essential for disc health and function
  • It is primarily composed of type II collagen and high proteoglycan content, contributing to its hydrophilic, gelatinous nature
  • It typically contains 80-90% water content in youth, decreasing with age, making 60-70% an underestimate
  • The proteoglycan to collagen ratio is high, enabling the nucleus to resist compressive forces by retaining water

Explanation of other options:

It is primarily composed of type I collagen (Option A): Incorrect - ;Type I collagen is mainly found in the annulus fibrosus, not the nucleus pulposus

It contains 60-70% water content (Option B): Incorrect - this underestimates the true water content in a healthy nucleus pulposus

Has a low proteoglycan to collagen ratio (Option C): Incorrect - the nucleus has a high proteoglycan content, critical for water retention

Key Takeaways:

  • Nucleus pulposus is avascular and nourished by diffusion from the vertebral end plates
  • Composed mainly of type II collagen and proteoglycans
  • Vital for shock absorption and disc hydration.

choices.text: The imaging study of choice is a CT myelogram
The presence of saddle anesthesia and bladder dysfunction predicts a poor prognosis for this patient.
Epidural steroid injection is the next best step in treatment
The patient's age predicts poor outcomes for this patient

questions.text: A 51-year-old male reports difficulty with urination and numbness in his bilateral buttocks. His symptoms began 12 hours ago. Which of the following statements about his condition is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This presentation is classic for cauda equina syndrome, a surgical emergency
  • The combination of saddle anesthesia and bladder dysfunction indicates severe nerve root involvement, and the prognosis worsens the longer decompression is delayed
  • Neurological deficits, such as urinary retention, are linked with poorer functional recovery, even after surgery

Explanation of other options:

The imaging study of choice is a CT myelogram (Option A): Incorrect - the investigation of choice is MRI, which provides superior soft tissue and nerve root visualization

Epidural steroid injection is the next best step in treatment (Option C): Incorrect - it is used in radiculopathy without red flag signs, not in cauda equina, which requires urgent surgical decompression

The patient's age predicts poor outcomes for this patient (Option D): Incorrect - neurological status at presentation and timing of decompression are more predictive than age

Key Takeaways:

  • Cauda equina syndrome presents with saddle anesthesia, bladder/bowel dysfunction, and lower limb weakness
  • Poor prognosis is linked to delayed surgery and the severity of initial deficits
  • MRI is the imaging of choice; treatment is urgent decompression.

questions.text: Contracture of which of the following muscles has been implicated as an etiology for congenital muscular torticollis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Congenital muscular torticollis is most commonly due to unilateral fibrosis and contracture of the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle
  • This leads to head tilt toward the affected side and chin rotation to the opposite side
  • Often associated with birth trauma, intrauterine malposition, or vascular compromise to the SCM

Explanation of other options:

Platysma (Option A): A superficial neck muscle, not involved in cervical rotation or head tilt

Omohyoid (Option B): An infrahyoid muscle, not associated with torticollis or postural deformity

Longus colli (Option C): A deep cervical flexor, not typically involved in torticollis pathogenesis

Key Takeaways:

  • Sternocleidomastoid contracture is the primary cause of congenital torticollis.
  • Early physiotherapy is crucial to prevent long-term deformity
  • Surgery is rarely needed but may be considered if conservative measures fail.

choices.text: It is a fracture through the pedicle at the pars interarticularis of the atlas
It is due to the distraction extension force
Mild injuries can be treated with rigid cervical support

questions.text: Select the false statement about Hangman's fracture
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hangman's fracture is a fracture of the pars interarticularis of the axis (C2), not the atlas (C1). Therefore, Option A is false
  • Typically results from hyperextension and axial loading, often seen in motor vehicle accidents or judicial hanging
  • While it can be potentially fatal due to involvement of the upper cervical spine, many cases survive, especially with early stabilization
  • Mild or non-displaced fractures (e.g., Levine Type I) can be managed conservatively using a rigid cervical collar or halo vest

Explanation of other options:

It is due to distraction extension force (Option B): True - classic mechanism of injury

Can be fatal (Option C): True - especially if associated with cord or vascular injury

Mild injuries can be treated with rigid cervical support (Option D): True - conservative treatment is effective for stable fractures

Key Takeaways:

  • Hangman's fracture = C2 pars interarticularis fracture
  • Atlas (C1) is not involved; misnaming it is a common error
  • Management depends on fracture stability; stable fractures are treated conservatively.

choices.text: Increased cell number in the nucleus pulposus

questions.text: Which of the following processes is involved in age-related intervertebral disc degeneration?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • With age, the nucleus pulposus, which is normally rich in Type II collagen and proteoglycans, undergoes fibrosis and becomes more like the annulus fibrosus, where Type I collagen predominates
  • This replacement results in loss of disc elasticity, decreased hydration, and reduced shock-absorbing capability
  • The disc becomes stiffer, contributing to degeneration and pain

Explanation of other options:

Increased cell number in the nucleus pulposus (Option A): False - cell density decreases due to apoptosis and senescence

Increased matrix synthesis (Option B): False - matrix production declines with aging

Increased disc height (Option C): False - disc height decreases due to reduced water content and matrix breakdown

Key Takeaways:

  • Aging leads to fibrosis and biochemical changes in the disc
  • Type II → Type I collagen shift signifies mechanical deterioration
  • A major factor in age-related spondylosis and chronic back pain.

questions.text: What is the fracture shown in the picture below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The CT scan shows a vertebral body burst fracture with retropulsion of bone fragments into the spinal canal, which suggests potential spinal cord or nerve root compression
  • This indicates disruption beyond the anterior and middle columns, possibly involving the posterior elements or ligaments, defining it as unstable
  • Unstable burst fractures pose a risk for neurological compromise and often require surgical stabilization

Explanation of other options:

Flexion distraction injury (Option A): Involves tearing of the posterior ligamentous complex, not compression; the pattern here is compressive, not distractive

Chance fracture (Option B): A horizontal fracture due to flexion-distraction across the vertebral body and posterior elements - not seen in this vertical/compressive fracture pattern

Stable burst fracture (Option C): Would show no posterior column disruption, and the posterior vertebral body wall would remain largely intact - not the case here, as retropulsed fragments indicate instability

Key Takeaways:

  • Unstable burst fractures involve compression with canal compromise and/or posterior column involvement
  • Differentiating stable vs. unstable is critical for management decisions
  • CT imaging is the gold standard for fracture classification

questions.text: A 28-year-old male falls from a height of approximately 15 feet and lands on his feet. He complains of severe back pain and inability to move his legs. On examination, there is tenderness over the thoracolumbar junction and reduced motor power in the lower limbs. Imaging reveals a vertebral body fracture with bony fragments retropulsed into the spinal canal. What is the most likely mechanism of injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Burst fractures occur due to axial compression forces, typically when a person falls from a height and lands on the feet or buttocks
  • The force is transmitted vertically through the spine, causing the vertebral body to shatter and burst outward, often with retropulsion into the spinal canal
  • These fractures may involve the anterior and middle columns, and are stable or unstable depending on posterior involvement

Explanation of other options:

Flexion (Option B): May cause wedge fractures, not burst patterns

Flexion - rotation (Option C): Typically leads to facet dislocation or fracture-dislocation, not burst fracture

Extension (Option D): Usually causes posterior element injuries, not vertebral body compression

Key Takeaways:

  • Axial loading is the classic mechanism for burst fractures
  • Common in falls from height or motor vehicle accidents
  • A CT scan is essential for identifying retropulsed fragments and determining stability.

questions.text: The spinal cord terminates as the conus medullaris at what vertebral level in adults?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In adults, the spinal cord typically terminates at the lower border of the L1 vertebra, forming the conus medullaris
  • Below this level lies the cauda equina, composed of lumbar and sacral nerve roots
  • This anatomical landmark is clinically important for lumbar punctures, which are performed below L2 to avoid cord injury

Explanation of other options:

Upper border of L1 (Option A): Slightly higher than the typical termination point; not the usual anatomical landmark

Upper border of L3 (Option C): Too low - this would place the spinal cord at risk during procedures like lumbar puncture, which are safely done below this level

Lower border of L3 (Option D): Incorrect - in adults, the cord does not extend this far

Key Takeaways:

  • The conus medullaris ends at the lower border of L1 in adults
  • Important for procedural safety, especially spinal anesthesia and lumbar puncture
  • In infants, termination is lower (around L3), hence the adjusted approach.

questions.text: A patient presents with a far lateral herniation of the L4-5 disc. Which of the following findings is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A far lateral disc herniation at L4-L5 typically compresses the L4 root, but in many cases, especially paramedian herniations, the L5 nerve root is affected
  • The L5 root innervates muscles responsible for ankle dorsiflexion (mainly tibialis anterior)
  • Damage leads to foot drop and difficulty with heel walking
  • The sensory supply of L5 includes the dorsum of the foot and the great toe

Mnemonic:
L4 = "Kick the floor" (knee extension)
L5 = "Lift the foot" (dorsiflexion of ankle)
S1 = "Stand on one" (plantarflexion - toe walking)

Explanation of other options:

Lateral foot numbness (Option A): Indicates S1 root involvement

Anterior thigh numbness (Option B): Suggests L3-L4 root involvement, not L5

Ankle plantar flexion weakness (Option D): Controlled by S1, not L5

Key Takeaways:

  • L5 root = dorsiflexion and great toe extension
  • Far lateral L4-L5 herniation typically compresses L5
  • Use spinal root mnemonics to correlate action with lesion.

questions.text: A 45-year-old manual labourer presents to the OPD with the acute onset of back pain that radiates to his right leg after carrying a heavy object. He also has mild weakness with ankle dorsiflexion on that side. What should be his initial treatment? His MRI is shown in Figure.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has acute lumbar radiculopathy, likely due to lumbar disc herniation (L4-L5), presenting with mild dorsiflexion weakness (L5 root)
  • Initial treatment is conservative, especially in the absence of significant motor deficit or bladder/bowel involvement
  • Includes NSAIDs, physical therapy, activity modification, and optionally external bracing (e.g., Taylor brace)

Explanation of other options:

Microdiscectomy (Option A): Considered if symptoms persist >6 weeks or if there is progressive motor weakness or cauda equina

Taylor brace (Option B): A supportive option, but not a standalone primary treatment - it's part of conservative therapy

Decompression only (Option C): Reserved for patients with neurological compromise or spinal stenosis, not first-line

Key Takeaways:

  • Mild radiculopathy from disc herniation = conservative management first
  • Taylor brace supports posture but is adjunctive, not definitive
  • Surgery is reserved for refractory or severe neurological deficits.

questions.text: An adult patient with a grade I isthmic spondylolisthesis at L5-S1 is most likely to have weakness of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Isthmic spondylolisthesis at L5-S1 typically compresses the L5 nerve root
  • The extensor hallucis longus (EHL) is primarily innervated by L5, and weakness leads to difficulty extending the great toe, a hallmark sign of L5 radiculopathy
  • This is the most common deficiency seen in low-grade (Grade I) L5-S1 spondylolisthesis

Explanation of other options:

Flexor hallucis longus (Option A): Innervated by tibial nerve (S2) - not primarily affected at L5-S1

Quadriceps (Option B): Supplied by femoral nerve (L2-L4) - not involved in L5-S1 pathology

Gastrocsoleus (Option C): Controlled by S1, leading to plantar flexion - not the primary weakness in L5 compression

Key Takeaways:

  • L5 root compression = weakness of EHL, leading to toe extension. The most common finding in L5-S1 spondylolisthesis
  • Important to localize root deficits for surgical planning and monitoring.

questions.text: Which of the following classification systems is used to grade spondylolisthesis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Meyerding classification is the standard system used to grade spondylolisthesis based on the percentage of anterior displacement of one vertebral body over another
  • It categorizes the slip into Grades I to V:
    • Grade I: 0-25%
    • Grade II: 26-50%
    • Grade III: 51-75%
    • Grade IV: 76-100%
    • Grade V (Spondyloptosis): >100%

Explanation of other options:

Quebec Task Force (Option A): Used to classify whiplash-associated disorders, not spondylolisthesis

Allen & Ferguson (Option B): Classifies subaxial cervical spine injuries, not lumbosacral slip

Miyazaki (Option C): Used to grade disc degeneration on MRI, not vertebral displacement

Key Takeaways:

  • Meyerding classification = gold standard for grading spondylolisthesis
  • Based on the % anterior translation of the vertebra.
  • Helps in treatment planning and assessing instability.

questions.text: Identify the sign shown in the x-ray below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The X-ray shows the Inverted Napoleon hat sign, which occurs when L5 has slipped forward over S1 in severe spondylolisthesis
  • On frontal radiograph, the overlapping vertebral bodies and their contours resemble an upside-down bicorne hat, also called the "Napoleon hat" appearance
  • This is most commonly seen in Grade III-V spondylolisthesis

Explanation of other options:

Spondylitis - Bamboo spine (Option A): Incorrect pairing; bamboo spine is correct, but spondylitis is too vague

Ankylosing spondylitis - Bamboo spine (Option B): Describes a different sign, seen on lateral view, not frontal

Spondylolysis - Scotty dog sign (Option D): Seen on oblique lumbar X-rays, represents a pars interarticularis defect

Key Takeaways:

  • Inverted Napoleon hat sign = severe spondylolisthesis on AP view
  • Important radiological clue in high-grade L5-S1 anterior displacement
  • Helps differentiate from other spinal deformities on plain films.

questions.text: Of the following signs or findings, which one is most consistent with the diagnosis of cervical radiculopathy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Spurling's sign is a provocative test for cervical radiculopathy, performed by extending, rotating, and applying axial compression on the head toward the symptomatic side
  • A positive test reproduces radicular pain, confirming nerve root compression
  • It has moderate sensitivity and high specificity, making it a valuable clinical tool

Explanation of other options:

Hoffman sign (Option B): Indicates corticospinal tract involvement - suggests myelopathy, not radiculopathy

Clonus (Option C): A sign of upper motor neuron lesion - seen in myelopathy, not isolated nerve root compression

Inverted brachioradialis reflex (Option D): Seen in cervical cord compression (C5-C6 myelopathy), not radiculopathy

Key Takeaways:

  • Spurling test = classic sign for cervical radiculopathy
  • Helps differentiate from myelopathy, which presents with UMN signs
  • Important in evaluating patients with neck pain and upper limb radiation.

questions.text: What is the most common presenting problem in patients with cauda equina syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The earliest and most common presenting symptom of cauda equina syndrome is severe lower back pain with radicular leg pain, often bilateral
  • This typically precedes the onset of more specific signs like urinary retention, saddle anesthesia, or motor deficits
  • Recognizing this early stage is critical for timely diagnosis and surgical intervention

Explanation of other options:

Urinary retention (Option A): A late sign, important for diagnosis but not the most common initial symptom

Unilateral lower limb motor loss (Option B): Suggestive of radiculopathy; cauda equina typically presents with bilateral symptoms due to multiple root involvement

Saddle numbness (Option C): A specific but less frequent initial symptom, often follows the onset of pain

Key Takeaways:

  • Back and radicular leg pain is the most frequent initial symptom in cauda equina syndrome
  • Later signs include bladder dysfunction, saddle anesthesia, and motor loss
  • Early MRI and decompression are essential to prevent irreversible damage.

choices.text: Results from osteonecrosis of the ring apophysis of the vertebral body
Most commonly involves the thoracic spine
Seen in the geriatric age group

questions.text: What is not correct about Scheuermann's disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Scheuermann's disease is a juvenile kyphosis that typically presents in adolescents, not the elderly
  • It is characterized by anterior wedging of ≥3 consecutive vertebrae, leading to a rigid kyphotic deformity, most commonly in the thoracic spine
  • The pathology involves osteochondrosis of the vertebral ring apophysis, possibly due to avascular necrosis
  • It is also more common in males and can be associated with back pain and cosmetic deformity during adolescence

Explanation of other options:

Results from osteonecrosis of the ring apophysis (Option A): True - this is a recognized pathophysiological mechanism

Most commonly involves the thoracic spine (Option B): True - especially T7-T9 region

More common in males (Option D): True - shows a male preponderance

Key Takeaways:

  • Scheuermann's disease = adolescent structural kyphosis
  • Typically affects the thoracic spine in teenage males
  • Not a disease of the geriatric population.

questions.text: The MRI image given below shows?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The MRI shows a focal herniation of the nucleus pulposus, with the base of the herniation narrower than the dome, characteristic of a disc extrusion
  • In disc extrusion, the nuclear material breaches the annulus fibrosus but remains connected to the parent disc
  • This is different from disc sequestration, where the fragment is completely detached

Explanation of other options:

Sequestered disc (Option B): Involves complete separation of the herniated fragment, which is not seen here

Disc bulge (Option C): Involves a broad-based, symmetric extension of the disc (usually >25% of circumference), not focal as in this image

None of the above (Option D): Incorrect, as this is a case of disc extrusion

Key Takeaways:

  • Disc extrusion = focal herniation with narrow base
  • Differentiation from bulge (broad-based) and sequestration (detached fragment) is crucial
  • MRI is the investigation of choice for classifying disc pathology.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with neck stiffness and difficulty swallowing. A lateral radiograph is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The radiograph demonstrates flowing ossification along the anterolateral aspect of multiple contiguous vertebrae, characteristic of DISH (Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis)
  • DISH typically affects older men and involves the thoracic or cervical spine, often leading to neck stiffness and dysphagia due to anterior osteophyte formation
  • Diagnostic criteria include:
    • Flowing ossification along at least four contiguous vertebrae
    • Preservation of intervertebral disc height
    • Absence of sacroiliac joint involvement

Explanation of other options:

Ankylosing spondylitis (Option A): Involves sacroiliac joints and shows bamboo spine on lateral views - not seen here

Cervical myelopathy (Option B): Refers to cord compression symptoms, not primarily associated with anterior flow of ossification

Congenital spinal stenosis (Option C): Causes a narrow canal, not anterior bridging or dysphagia

Key Takeaways:

  • DISH presents with flowing anterior spinal ossification and may cause dysphagia
  • Distinguished from ankylosing spondylitis by lack of sacroiliac involvement
  • Diagnosis is radiological, confirmed by classical flowing calcifications.

questions.text: Which artery labelled in the figure provides the predominant blood supply to the spinal cord?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The artery labeled A in the diagram is the anterior spinal artery
  • It is responsible for supplying the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord, including the anterior horns and lateral corticospinal tracts
  • This makes it the predominant arterial supply to the spinal cord

Explanation of other options:

B (Option A): Represents the posterior spinal artery, which supplies only the posterior one-third of the cord

C (Option D): Likely a radicular artery, contributing segmentally but not the primary source

D (Option C): May represent a posterior radiculomedullary branch, also not the main supply

Key Takeaways:

  • Anterior spinal artery = major supply to the spinal cord
  • Infarcts here cause anterior spinal artery syndrome: motor loss with preserved posterior column sensations
  • Important in vascular, traumatic, and surgical spinal pathology.

choices.text: Angulated fracture of the odontoid process
Bilateral fractures through the C2 pars interarticularis
Displaced fracture of the C2 spinous process
Endplate to endplate fracture of the C1 vertebral body

questions.text: Which best describes a hangman fracture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A Hangman fracture is defined as a bilateral fracture of the pars interarticularis of the C2 vertebra (axis)
  • Typically results from hyperextension and distraction forces, such as in motor vehicle accidents
  • It often causes anterior displacement of C2 over C3, but rarely results in spinal cord injury due to a relatively wide spinal canal at this level

Explanation of other options:

Angulated fracture of the odontoid process (Option A): Describes a dens fracture, not a Hangman fracture

Displaced fracture of the C2 spinous process (Option C): Refers to a Clay-shoveler's fracture, not Hangman

Endplate to endplate fracture of the C1 vertebral body (Option D): Seen in Jefferson fracture, due to axial loading

Key Takeaways:

  • Hangman fracture = C2 bilateral pars fracture
  • Mechanism: hyperextension + distraction
  • Diagnosis confirmed via lateral cervical spine X-ray or CT.

questions.text: A 48-year-old office worker presents with an acute onset of lower back pain radiating to the left leg after lifting a heavy object. The pain follows a dermatomal pattern and worsens with coughing and forward bending. Based on your clinical suspicion of intervertebral disc prolapse, at which lumbar level is disc herniation most commonly seen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Approximately 90% of lumbar disc herniations occur at the L4-L5 and L5-S1 levels, with L4-L5 being the most commonly affected
  • This level bears significant mechanical stress and has the highest range of motion, making it prone to disc degeneration and herniation
  • L4-L5 herniation typically compresses the L5 nerve root, leading to foot drop and weakness of the extensor hallucis longus

Explanation of other options:

L1-L2 (Option A): Rarely involved in disc herniation; high lumbar levels are less mobile

L2-L3 (Option B): Uncommon site for herniation

L3-L4 (Option C): Less frequently involved than L4-L5

Key Takeaways:

  • L4-L5 and L5-S1 account for >90% of lumbar disc herniations
  • L4-L5 disc herniation commonly affects the L5 nerve root
  • Diagnosis is best confirmed with MRI, especially when radicular symptoms are present.

questions.text: Sciatic nerve damage is most commonly due to which of the following causes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most common cause of sciatic nerve damage is iatrogenic injury, particularly during intramuscular injections in the gluteal region
  • Improper technique, especially injecting in the inferomedial quadrant, can injure the sciatic nerve
  • Other iatrogenic causes include hip surgeries, arthroplasty, or incorrect positioning during procedures

Explanation of other options:

Degenerative (Option A): More commonly causes radiculopathy, not direct sciatic nerve damage

Traumatic (Option C): Includes fractures or dislocations (e.g., posterior hip dislocation), but is less common than iatrogenic causes

Vascular (Option D): Rarely causes isolated sciatic nerve injury

Key Takeaways:

  • Iatrogenic injury, especially via gluteal injection, is the leading cause of sciatic nerve damage.
  • Always use the upper outer quadrant for intramuscular injections in the gluteal region to avoid nerve injury.y
  • Clinical features include foot drop, posterior thigh and leg pain, and sensory deficits.

choices.text: Anaesthesia below the level of the lesion
Hyperreflexia at the level of the lesion

questions.text: Complete transection of the spinal cord at the C7 level produces all of the following effects except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A complete spinal cord transection at C7 results in:
    • Spinal shock in the acute phase, characterized by areflexia, flaccid paralysis, and loss of sensation below the lesion
    • Hypotension due to loss of sympathetic tone (neurogenic shock)
    • Limited respiratory effort, especially if the accessory muscles (innervated below C5) are affected
    • Loss of all modalities of sensation below the lesion
  • Hyperreflexia is a late finding in the recovery phase and is not present acutely at or below the level of the lesion, and certainly not at the level of the lesion

Explanation of other options:

Hypotension (Option A): True - due to autonomic disruption

Limited respiratory effort (Option B): True - due to intercostal and accessory muscle involvement, although the diaphragm (C3-C5) is spared

Anaesthesia below the level of the lesion (Option C): True - reflects complete sensory loss from spinal transection

Key Takeaways:

  • Acute complete spinal cord injury = areflexia + flaccid paralysis (not hyperreflexia)
  • Hyperreflexia appears weeks later as upper motor neuron signs emerge
  • C7 injury causes quadriplegia with some arm function (triceps spared).

questions.text: A 40-year-old male, after RTA, sustains a cervical spine injury. His lower limb power is greater than that of the upper limb, and sacral sensations are present. What type of spinal cord lesion is this?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Central cord syndrome typically occurs after hyperextension injuries in the cervical spine, particularly in patients with pre-existing cervical spondylosis
  • It presents with greater motor weakness in the upper limbs than the lower limbs due to the somatotopic organization of the corticospinal tract (upper limb fibers are more central)
  • Sacral sparing (presence of sacral sensation) is a key distinguishing feature

Explanation of other options:

Anterior cord syndrome (Option B): Involves motor loss and pain/temperature loss, but preserves posterior column functions; motor loss is usually complete and symmetrical

Posterior cord syndrome (Option C): Characterized by loss of proprioception and vibration, with preserved motor function

Brown-Sequard syndrome (Option D): Presents with ipsilateral motor loss and contralateral pain/temperature loss- not matching this bilateral pattern of upper > lower limb involvement

Key Takeaways:

  • Central cord syndrome = upper limb weakness > lower limb, with sacral sparing
  • Commonly caused by cervical hyperextension injury
  • Distinct from Brown-Séquard and anterior/posterior cord syndromes based on symptom pattern.

questions.text: Spinal injuries without any radiological abnormalities are found in which of the following age groups?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This presentation is typical of Spinal Cord Injury Without Radiographic Abnormality (SCIWORA), a condition most commonly seen in infants and young children
  • Their spines are more flexible and elastic, allowing spinal cord injury without bony damage visible on X-ray or CT
  • MRI is often the only modality that detects cord edema or hemorrhage

Explanation of other options:

Young adults (Option A): More prone to fracture-dislocations, not SCIWORA

Old people (Option B): Typically suffer from degenerative spine disease and fractures, with radiographic changes present

Teenagers (Option C): Closer to adult biomechanics; less likely than infants to exhibit SCIWORA

Key Takeaways:

  • SCIWORA = spinal cord injury with normal X-ray/CT, seen in young children
  • MRI is essential for diagnosis
  • Occurs due to ligamentous and cord elasticity in the pediatric spine.

questions.text: Regarding Hangman's fracture true statement is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hangman's fracture is a bilateral pars interarticularis fracture of C2, usually caused by hyperextension and distraction
  • It typically has a good prognosis, and bony union is common with conservative treatment (e.g., cervical collar or halo vest) in stable cases
  • Surgery is reserved for unstable fractures or failed conservative management
  • Mortality is not high, especially compared to high cervical cord injuries or dens fractures

Explanation of other options:

High post-admission mortality (Option A): Incorrect - most patients survive and recover with appropriate care

The most common axis fracture (Option B): False - Odontoid fractures are more common than Hangman's fractures

Surgical treatment is always necessary (Option C): False - many cases are managed non-operatively

Key Takeaways:

  • Hangman's fracture = C2 pars fracture, commonly treated non-surgically
  • Union is common, especially in Type I and II fractures
  • Surgery is not mandatory unless the fracture is unstable or non-united.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed motor vehicle accident. He is unconscious initially but regains consciousness with complete flaccid paralysis, areflexia, and loss of all sensory modalities below the T6 level. Over the next few days, neurological monitoring is performed to assess for the return of spinal cord activity. Which reflex, if present, would indicate the end of spinal shock?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The bulbocavernous reflex (BCR) is typically the first spinal reflex to return after the acute areflexic phase of spinal shock
  • Its return signifies the end of spinal shock, even if motor and sensory function have not yet returned
  • Absence of BCR in the early stages is expected; its reemergence indicates spinal cord circuitry is intact

Explanation of other options:

Plantar reflex (Option A): Not reliable in spinal shock; can be influenced by supraspinal centers

Knee reflex (Option B): Returns later; not used to define the end of spinal shock

Biceps reflex (Option C): Not relevant to thoracolumbar injuries; segmentally inappropriate

Key Takeaways:

  • Bulbocavernous reflex = first returning reflex post spinal shock
  • Assessed by glans penis squeeze or Foley tug → anal sphincter contraction
  • Critical for prognosis and clinical staging.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to her GP with a longstanding history of lower back pain, which has suddenly worsened in severity over the past few days. An urgent MRI scan of the lumbar spine shows a right paracentral disc protrusion at the L4/L5 level. The disc impinges on the lateral recess at this level. The most likely outcome would be
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A paracentral disc protrusion at L4/L5 typically compresses the L5 nerve root
  • The extensor hallucis longus (EHL) is innervated predominantly by L5, and its weakness leads to difficulty extending the great toe
  • This is one of the earliest and most reliable signs of L5 radiculopathy

Explanation of other options:

Cauda equina syndrome (Option A): Would require central disc herniation with bilateral symptoms, bladder/bowel dysfunction, and saddle anesthesia, which are not described here

Lumbar plexus compression (Option B): Not applicable; plexus is higher up (L1-L4), and the lesion here is nerve root-specific

Loss of ankle dorsiflexion (Option C): Indicates deep peroneal nerve/L4 root involvement, more commonly seen in L3-L4 herniation

Key Takeaways:

  • L4-L5 paracentral disc = L5 root compression
  • L5 root = EHL weakness → trouble extending the great toe
  • Use dermatomal and myotomal correlation for lesion localization.

questions.text: The Turnbuckle cast is used for
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Turnbuckle cast is a mechanical orthosis used primarily in the correction of scoliosis, especially postural and early structural scoliosis
  • It allows gradual, controlled correction through adjustable tension, making it ideal for non-surgical spinal deformity management
  • Particularly effective in children and adolescents with flexible curves

Explanation of other options:

Spinal TB with deformity (Option B): Managed with antitubercular therapy and, if required, surgical stabilization- not with Turnbuckle cast

Hangman's fracture (Option C): Requires cervical immobilization, typically via halo vest or rigid collar

Cervical spine injury (Option D): Managed with rigid immobilization or surgical fixation, depending on severity - Turnbuckle cast is not indicated

Key Takeaways:

  • Turnbuckle cast = used for gradual correction in scoliosis
  • Not suitable for infective, traumatic, or high cervical pathologies
  • Employed in pediatric orthopedics and rehabilitative spine care.
